title: Gamma Knife Treatment for Acoustic Tumor
chief_complaint: I have noticed hearing loss for several years and I hear ringing in both ears.

problem_summary.onset: Several years prior to initial evaluation.
problem_summary.course: Progressive, particularly in the right ear.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral initially, becoming asymmetric (Right worse than Left).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral tinnitus; later developed slight imbalance.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation prompted by family history of hearing loss.

history.present_illness: Patient reported hearing loss for several years and bilateral tinnitus.
history.otologic_history: Mother had hearing loss. Otherwise negative otologic history.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild to moderate bilateral sensorineural hearing loss through 2000 Hz, rising to slight loss at 3000-4000 Hz. Asymmetry noted in high frequencies (Right worse at 6-8 kHz).

numeric_results.RE_thresholds: Moderate loss at 6000 Hz, moderately severe at 8000 Hz.
numeric_results.LE_thresholds: Slight loss at 6000 Hz, mild loss at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech recognition thresholds (SRT) consistent with pure tones. Word recognition scores (WRS) within normal limits bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral and contralateral thresholds within normal limits. Reflex decay negative.

history.present_illness: Patient returned 3-4 years later reporting progression of hearing loss in the right ear and slight imbalance. No vertigo.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear stable. Right ear shows significant decrease in air conduction thresholds. Slight conductive component (15-20 dB) at 250-1000 Hz in Right Ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left WRS normal. Right WRS slightly impaired at 90 dB HL and moderately impaired at 100 dB HL (rollover not significant).

numeric_results.RE_WRS: 80% at 90 dB HL, 64% at 100 dB HL

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear negative pressure (-140 daPa) likely causing low-frequency air-bone gaps. Left ear normal.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right contralateral reflexes elevated at 500 and 2000 Hz. Positive acoustic reflex decay at 1000 Hz in the Right Ear.

history.otologic_history: Diagnosed with right acoustic tumor (vestibular schwannoma) after V2. Underwent Gamma Knife radiosurgery approx 5 months after V2. Serial MRIs showed tumor stability.
history.prior_management: Gamma Knife radiation. Fit with Left BTE hearing aid initially. Later fit with BiCROS system.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear progressed to severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear thresholds remained stable.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear WRS very poor. Left ear WRS slightly impaired.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: All right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent (noted in text during interim follow-up).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient initially presented with mild-to-moderate bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Over a 10-year period, the left ear remained stable, while the right ear demonstrated significant progressive loss, eventually becoming severe-to-profound following Gamma Knife treatment for a vestibular schwannoma. Word recognition in the right ear deteriorated from normal (96%) to very poor (18%), consistent with retrocochlear pathology.
counseling_points: The MRI confirmed a small acoustic tumor on your right hearing nerve, which explains the difference in hearing between your ears.
Gamma Knife radiation has stabilized the tumor growth, but as often happens, the hearing on that side has continued to decline.
Because your right ear can no longer understand speech clearly, a standard hearing aid on that side won't help.
We recommend a BiCROS system: a microphone on your right ear will wirelessly send sound to a hearing aid in your better left ear, helping you hear people on your bad side.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is initially unconcerned about the asymmetry but becomes worried as the right ear deteriorates.
In the final visit, express frustration with hearing on the right side but satisfaction with the BiCROS solution if asked about current management.
Report imbalance only during the second visit (V2).
